body:
Hi @nilday: Thanks for the question. One of the ways to get around this would be `import pyarrow` and `HadoopFileSystem` locally inside constructor for `HdfsArtifactRepository`. Something like this-

```
class HdfsArtifactoryRepository(ArtifactRepository):
    def __init__(self, ...):
            import pyarrow
            from pyarrow.hdfs import connect
            self.hdfs = connect(...)
    # implement other methods
```

Most of the model flavors (h2o, keras, pytorch ... etc) do it this way due to the same reason. As you rightly noted the heavy dependency is not loaded automatically. 
Note: test harness already installs `pyarrow`.

One quick question: What is the nature of your project? As you mentioned WebHDFS is a lighter protocol. What are the requirements that are necessitating a native hdfs support?

@mparkhe webhdfs protocol does not support ha. It's not a big problem because I find python hdfs client support ha ha in client end. In some cases, the hadoop cluster may disable webhdfs protocol. I think it's just a trade off, whether support more feathers with heavier dependency or just use lighter protocol. 
How about use pyarrow native libhdfs  by default and fallback to webhdfs if it's pyarrow or libhdfs not installed?(But there is still a problem: hdfs and webhdfs default ports are different, we cannot indicate  two ports at the same for fallback usage without introducing new configuration )

I think it would be cleaner to have these are separate artifact repos classes. I agree with concern about increase import time and additional dependencies. It would be cleanest to import `pyarrow` only in the `__init__` function to instantiate the file system handler.

Do you want to submit a pull request for a native `HdfsArtifactRepository` using `pyarrow` library? If needed we can write another `WebHdfsArtifactRepository` in future if there is a use case for it.

Thanks!
Yes I would submit a pull request. I've finished coding work. I will submit a pr as soon as I write some test and document.

@mparkhe hello, I've finished main code a long time, but I have some problem dealing with unit test. I'm not very familiar with python Mock, so I find it really hard for me to write the right unit test. Would you mind I submit without unit test? Or you don't mind wait a little longer so that I could figure out how to write the right unit test?
@nilday is there any progress on the HDFS artifact repository? We would be also interested in using it.
We are working on hdfs artifact repository https://github.com/kiranvaranasi81/mlflow/commits/hadoop_artifact. We will soon raise pull request completing our testing.
got it. I will take a look. There is a chance we will start using mlflow and this is an important part we miss.

Dear all, we are interesting in using MLFlow. Just wonder if the HDFS support (as the DB to store the ML models) is currently implemented in MLFlow?
Thanks
@nilday @mparkhe guess we can close this issue?
